sentences.sentence: Retirement savings Australia's overdue reforms would bring investor protections into line with the US portfolio market 46 years later.The superannuation portfolio disclosure reforms that are being tweaked by the government have caused quite a bit of consternation across the investment industry.

Opposition to the reforms has come at the highest level, for example, Greg Combet (Opinion, October 6).To put it simply, the very large - and dominant - industry super sector is questioning long overdue reform measures.One would hope that the motivation for these changes is to provide more protection for the retirement savings of tens of millions of ordinary Australians, who are forced to hand over contributions to fund managers who, judging by their opposition to additional scrutiny, may not have their best interests at heart.However, we do not wish to be too critical of the union-dominated funds, which have generally outperformed bank-provided funds, and which are recognised as innovators in the implementation of their investment arrangements.In setting out to reform the industry, the government needed to look no further than the world's largest portfolio market - the US - to identify world-best regulatory practice.In a market many times the size of Australia's but without the compulsion, all large funds are required to publicly report to their regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the detailed valuations of assets on a quarterly basis (initially it was six-monthly).

Thus, all investors are provided with a snapshot of their retirement wealth every quarter, from which they can deduce the net buys and sells across all asset types, and hence decide whether they approve of the direction of their fund's strategy.When Australia's government turned its attention to the US, it became glaringly obvious that our regulators - the Australian Securities and Investments Commission and the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority - had either been asleep at the wheel, or had succumbed to fund lobbying power.

Not merely for decade but through all of 46 years since the US Congress introduced these crucial reforms.We are entitled to ask why the necessary reforms to protect Australian investors have been delayed for so long.

The explanation cannot be the quality of the arguments put up by investment managers to preserve the highly opaque status quo.Combet objects to the disclosure of valuations of illiquid unlisted assets on the spurious grounds that this will assist buyers in negotiating a lower price: the vendor of a house does not "scream out the reserve price to the auction's bidders".By conflating a valuation with the reserve price, Combet is doing a disservice to the negotiating astuteness of his own very able investment managers.State governments provide rateable land valuations for every property.

We never see investment managers objecting to publicly displayed property valuations that are entirely divorced from reserve prices.Funds and investors generally are the beneficiaries of more active and better-informed markets, especially for relatively illiquid assets.

So why are super fund managers so opposed to even a modicum of information being provided?In essence, detailed quarterly portfolio composition information for investment managers is no different from asset valuations and cash flow statements compulsorily provided by every company auditor.
Why should the entire industry be a protected political class?They are already far more privileged than mere companies that are not protected by compulsion.

We do not see super fund managers decrying the provision of audited company information designed to help both fund managers and the public.If Combet and super fund managers were really concerned with investor protection, they would not be raising questionable analogies with reserve prices at auction.

Rather, they would argue that sometimes disclosures designed to improve accountability might prematurely, and adversely, disclose an individual fund's investment strategy.But the US Congress foreshadowed this problem in 1975 by allowing a reporting delay.
This is currently up to 45 days with respect to quarterly holdings.

Moreover, US funds that are prepared to privately reveal their investment strategy to the SEC can gain a longer delay if they can establish their investors will be harmed.The portfolio holdings disclosure regime offers a new and important accountability mechanism that should serve all participants, including fund managers, well.While some elements of the reforms have justifiably caused industry participants some trepidation - for example, the different treatment of the government's Future Fund, it is time for Australia, the world's fourth-largest pension fund market, to deliver international standards of best practice to better protect investors.
These protocols have operated very effectively in the US since 1975; we're 46 years behind the eight ball.
Catching up is way overdue.David R. Gallagher is at the RoZetta Institute and is a former professor at UNSW Business School.
Peter L. Swan is a professor of finance at UNSW Business School.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Retirement savings Australia's overdue reforms would bring investor protections into line with the US portfolio market 46 years later.The superannuation portfolio disclosure reforms that are being tweaked by the government have caused quite a bit of consternation across the investment industry. Opposition to the reforms has come at the highest level, for example, Greg Combet (Opinion, October 6).To put it simply, the very large - and dominant - industry super sector is questioning long overdue reform measures.One would hope that the motivation for these changes is to provide more protection for the retirement savings of tens of millions of ordinary Australians, who are forced to hand over contributions to fund managers who, judging by their opposition to additional scrutiny, may not have their best interests at heart.However, we do not wish to be too critical of the union-dominated funds, which have generally outperformed bank-provided funds, and which are recognised as innovators in the implementation of their investment arrangements.In setting out to reform the industry, the government needed to look no further than the world's largest portfolio market - the US - to identify world-best regulatory practice.In a market many times the size of Australia's but without the compulsion, all large funds are required to publicly report to their regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the detailed valuations of assets on a quarterly basis (initially it was six-monthly). Thus, all investors are provided with a snapshot of their retirement wealth every quarter, from which they can deduce the net buys and sells across all asset types, and hence decide whether they approve of the direction of their fund's strategy.When Australia's government turned its attention to the US, it became glaringly obvious that our regulators - the Australian Securities and Investments Commission and the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority - had either been asleep at the wheel, or had succumbed to fund lobbying power. The explanation cannot be the quality of the arguments put up by investment managers to preserve the highly opaque status quo.Combet objects to the disclosure of valuations of illiquid unlisted assets on the spurious grounds that this will assist buyers in negotiating a lower price: the vendor of a house does not "scream out the reserve price to the auction's bidders".By conflating a valuation with the reserve price, Combet is doing a disservice to the negotiating astuteness of his own very able investment managers.State governments provide rateable land valuations for every property. So why are super fund managers so opposed to even a modicum of information being provided?In essence, detailed quarterly portfolio composition information for investment managers is no different from asset valuations and cash flow statements compulsorily provided by every company auditor. Why should the entire industry be a protected political class?They are already far more privileged than mere companies that are not protected by compulsion. We do not see super fund managers decrying the provision of audited company information designed to help both fund managers and the public.If Combet and super fund managers were really concerned with investor protection, they would not be raising questionable analogies with reserve prices at auction. Moreover, US funds that are prepared to privately reveal their investment strategy to the SEC can gain a longer delay if they can establish their investors will be harmed.The portfolio holdings disclosure regime offers a new and important accountability mechanism that should serve all participants, including fund managers, well.While some elements of the reforms have justifiably caused industry participants some trepidation - for example, the different treatment of the government's Future Fund, it is time for Australia, the world's fourth-largest pension fund market, to deliver international standards of best practice to better protect investors. These protocols have operated very effectively in the US since 1975; we're 46 years behind the eight ball. Catching up is way overdue.David R. Gallagher is at the RoZetta Institute and is a former professor at UNSW Business School. Peter L. Swan is a professor of finance at UNSW Business School.
